     abdomen, concentrating on the liver and biliary tree.  No IV contrast was
     administered secondary to inability to obtain access.
     
     Comparison is made to ultrasound examinations from [**3225-11-26**], [**3225-10-20**], and from ERCP dated [**3225-11-13**].
     
     MRCP WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Since the ERCP of [**3225-11-13**], there has been
     interval decompression of the distal extrahepatic bile duct.  There is no
     intrahepatic biliary dilatation.  The region of the choledocho-choledocho
     anastomosis is not definitively identified due to a surrounding lobulated
     fluid collection measuring approximately 5.5 x 5 x 3 cm.  The walls of this
     collection are thin but show clumped internal low signal consistent with
     debris. It is not possible to determine if this collection is connected to the
     biliary system.  Since it is not seen on ERCP from [**3225-11-13**], it is
     likely an extrabiliary collection.
     
     There is no free fluid seen around the liver hilum or within the abdomen.
     There is no evidence of solid or cystic liver lesion/mass. Normal signal is
     seen within the pancreas and kidneys.  There is a 4 x 3.4 x 8.1 (SI, AP,
     transverse) subdiaphragmatic, perihepatic hematoma along the
     superior/posterior portion of the right liver.  Fluid is still seen within the
     surgical incision.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Interval decompression of the distal extrahepatic common duct.
     
     2.  Lobulated fluid collection surrounding the biliary anastomosis.  This
     collection appeared to be present on the ultrasound dated 4 o'clock 2004. ERCP
     findings suggest that it is not connected to the biliary tree. HIDA scan could
     be useful for confirmation.  Although the biliary anastamosis is not
     identified the lack of intrahepatic biliary dilatation and lack of interval
     formation of free abdominal fluid strongly argues against an anastomotic
     breakdown.
     
     I discussed these findings with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1081**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1082**] via telephone on [**11-26**]

     clinical correlation is recommended.

     is identified in a subcutaneous position corresponding to the surgical scar.
     Posterosuperiorly is identified a perihepatic fluid collection, known from MR
     to have complex characteristics consistent with hematoma and noted on CT to
     have some dependent layering density, also consistent with hematoma.

     innterposed fat, which represents the debris seen on MR examination.  There is

     choledochojejunostomy anastomosis are not well seen.  No other collection is
     identified on CT.

      58 year old man with recent liver transplant. Now with rising alk phos. Liver
      bx suggests obstruction. 
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      rising LFTs s/p liver transplant
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: 58 year old with recent liver transplant, now with rising
     alkaline phosphatase.
     
     Fluoroscopic assistance was provided to the gastroenterologist without a
     radiologist present. 17 spot images are provided for interpretation.
     
     FINDINGS:
     There is a size mismatch of the native and donor common bile ducts with mild
     dilation of the native common bile duct. The donor common bile duct is normal
     in appearance. Several small sacular areas are seen in the region of the
     proximal native common bile duct which were not appreciated on the prior
     study. However, these are present on an MRI performed [**3225-11-26**]. The
     intrahepatic ducts demonstrate areas of narrowing and dilation. No filling
     defects are identified. There is no mass.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     Size mismatch between the native and donor common bile ducts with mild
     dilation of the native common bile duct. Pruning and dilation of the
     intrahepatic ducts suggests a cholangitis or PSC-type process.

     INDICATION:  58 year old liver transplant patient with rising liver function
     tests.

     the pubic symphysis following the administration of 100 cc of Visipaque.
     Visipaque was used due to patient renal insufficiency.  Images were obtained
     in the arterial, portal venous, and delayed phases.
     
     Multiplanar reformatted images were created.
     
     COMPARISON:  [**3225-11-28**].
     
     CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST:  The visualized lung bases
     again demonstrate patchy opacification within the right middle lobe,
     concerning for infection.  There are no pleural or pericardial effusions.  The
     liver demonstrates homogeneous enhancement throughout.  Portal vein, hepatic
     arteries, and hepatic veins are patent.  There is now mild central biliary
     ductal dilatation, a finding which is not appreciated in the prior noncontrast
     exam.  There is a stable appearing 4.0 x 8.6 cm posterior subphrenic fluid
     collection with high density material within it consistent with clot.  In
     addition, there is a stable appearing 4.3 x 4.4 cm hepatic hilar fluid
     collection containing fat.  The extrahepatic portion of the bile duct and the
     choledochocholedochal anastomosis is not well appreciated.  Extensive
     postoperative changes are present along the anterior abdominal wall with fluid
     within the rectus muscles.  The spleen is normal in appearance.  The pancreas
     is markedly atrophic.  The adrenal glands and kidneys appear grossly normal.
     There is a calcified left lower pole renal lesion which likely represents a
     cyst.  There are tiny bilateral low attenuation renal foci which are too small
     to characterize further.  The stomach and visualized loop of small and large
     bowel ate unremarkable.  The aorta and its major intra-abdominal branches are
     patent.  There is no free air.
     
     CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The urinary bladder, distal ureters,
     seminal vesicles and prostate gland are within normal limits.  Pelvic loops of
     bowel are unremarkable.  There is no free fluid or air.
     
     BONE WINDOWS:  There is a probable healed fracture of the right iliac [**Doctor First Name 198**].
     The osseous structures are otherwise unremarkable.

     Reason: S/P LIVER TX 2 MOPNTHS, EVAL FOR VASCULAR FLOW IN VESSELS
     Admitting Diagnosis: ELEVATED LFTS;S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
       58 year old man with elevation in LFT's s/p liver transplant 2 months ago      
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      vascular flow ?                                                                 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  Fifty-eight-year-old man with elevated LFTs status post liver
     transplant 2 months ago.
     
     COMPARISON:  [**3225-11-26**].
     
     Again seen in Segment VI, there is an area of increased echogenicity, which is
     stable compared to previous study.  No other focal or textural liver
     abnormalities are seen.  There is no biliary ductal dilatation.  Small
     subhepatic collection is also again seen and unchanged in appearance.
     
     The main left and right portal veins are widely patent with hepatopetal flow.
     The main left and right hepatic arteries are widely patent with resistive
     indices ranging from 0.68 to 0.77.  The right middle and left hepatic veins
     are patent with appropriate direction of flow.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1)  Widely patent hepatic arteries, portal veins, and hepatic veins with
     appropriate resistive indices within the hepatic arteries.
     2)  Stable appearance of echogenic area in Segment VI of the liver and small
     subhepatic collection.

     INDICATION:  Status post liver transplant, now with rising alkaline
     phosphatase.
     
     COMPARISON:  [**3225-11-26**].
     
     TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar MRCP of the liver including T1W in and out of phase,
     STIR, HASTE, and 3D dynamic T1W fat sat imaging sequences without and with IV
     Gadolinium contrast.  Subtracted and multiplanar reformatted images were
     generated on an external workstation.
     
     FINDINGS:  There is abnormal intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation which is
     at least moderate in severity, particularly in the the setting of liver
     transplantation.  The common hepatic duct is followed to the region of the 4.3
     x 3.0 cm fluid collection in the region of the biliary anastomosis.  The
     distal (presumably native) common bile duct is within normal limits, but a 1.5
     cm segment of the common bile duct in the region of the anastomosis (mid-CBD)
     is not seen.  The fluid collection adjacent to the biliary anastomosis is
     slightly smaller on today's study, but the amount of fluid tracking into the
     region of the falciform ligament has increased in the interval.  No focal
     hepatic mass is seen.
     
     There is a small right pleural effusion.  Multiple small simple renal cysts
     are present bilaterally.  The kidneys demonstrate prompt and symmetric
     contrast enhancement.  The pancreas is somewhat atrophic.  The adrenal glands,
     spleen, and visualized portions of bowel are unremarkable.  There are
     postsurgical changes within the anterior abdominal wall, with fluid still seen
     within the surgical inscision site.
     
     Multiplanar reformatted images were essential.
     
     IMPRESSION:  1.  Intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation, probably at least
     moderate in severity in a patient who is status post liver transplantation.
     
     2.  Abnormal mid segment of the common bile duct, with no normal common bile
     duct seen in the region of the biliary anastomosis.  This finding is
     concerning for stenosis of the common bile duct in the region of the
     anastomosis.
     
     3.  While the lobulated fluid collection surrounding the biliary anastomosis
     has slightly decreased in size, the amount of fluid tracking along the

     MRI ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST                                        Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14970**]
     Reason: ABDOMINAL PAIN
     Admitting Diagnosis: BILIARY STENOSCS
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  Abdominal pain, evaluate for common bile duct anastomotic
     stricture, status post liver transplantation.
     
     TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar MRCP of the liver at 3-Tesla including 3D FR FSE and
     HASTE imaging sequences.  Multiplanar and MIP reformatted images were
     generated on an external workstation.
     
     FINDINGS:  3D MRCP imaging sequences provide better evaluation of the
     extrahepatic biliary system.  There is narrowing within the mid common bile
     duct, likely at the site of surgical anastomosis.  The native common bile duct
     is mildly prominent measuring 10 mm in diameter.  The transplant common bile
     duct is also mildly prominent measuring up to 9 mm in diameter.  There is
     intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation.  Multiple intrahepatic biliary
     strictures are seen, particularly within the more central portion of the
     intrahepatic ducts on both the right and left.  Incidentally noted is a cystic
     duct remnant.  The fluid collection adjacent to the biliary anastomosis
     tracking along the falciform ligament is unchanged compared to [**3225-12-17**].  Postsurgical changes and small collections within the anterior
     abdominal wall are partially imaged, but appear unchanged.
     
     Generation of MIP and multiplanar reformatted images was essential.
     
     IMPRESSIONS:  1.  Narrowing within the mid common bile duct, likely at the
     side of surgical anastomosis. Compared to prior ERCP there is no
     significant mismatch in caliber between donor and native CBD. This suggests
     dilatation of native CBD during prior ERCP due to injection of contrast
     against stenosis at the anastomosis.
     
     2.  Dilated intrahepatic biliary ducts on both the right and left with
     multiple intrahepatic biliary ductal strictures, particularly within the
     central portion of the intrahepatic ducts.
     
     3.  Unchanged fluid collection adjacent to the CBD anastomosis and tracking
     along the falciform ligament.

     INDICATION:  A 58-year-old man with recent liver transplant, now with rising
     liver function tests.  Recent ERCP with sphincterotomy and sludge extraction.
     Rule out biliary obstruction.
     
     Comparison is made with a prior ERCP dated [**3225-12-2**].
     
     ERCP:  Nine images were provided for radiology interpretation.  ERCP was
     performed by the gastroenterologist under fluoroscopic guidance.  No
     radiologist was present during the image acquisition.
     
     Proximal portion of the common bile duct is moderately dilated.  There is
     approximately 5-mm stricture within the middle-third of the common bile duct,
     which is preceded by a focal area of dilatation.  Presumably, this is at the
     site of anastomosis.  This is in accordance with prior reports, which
     demonstrate size mismatch between the native and donor common bile ducts.
     
     A biliary stent is seen extending across the area of stricture within images
     #8 and #9.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     Common bile duct stricture, with focus of proximal dilatation, presumably at
     the site of anastomosis.  Biliary stent was placed across the area of the
     stricture.

     DATE: [**3225-12-19**] 1:15 PM
     BX-NEEDLE LIVER BY RADIOLOGIST; GUIDANCE/LOCALIZATION FOR NEEDLE BIOPSY US (S&I)Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14971**]
     Reason: please bx liver - r/o rejection                             
     Admitting Diagnosis: BILIARY STENOSCS
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      58 year old man s/p OLT [**3225-10-3**], s/p ERCP yesterday and stent placement         
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please bx liver - r/o rejection                                                 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  Status post liver transplant, presents for biopsy to rule out
     rejection.
     
     LIVER BIOPSY BY RADIOLOGIST:  The potential risks and benefits of the
     procedure were explained in detail with the patient.  Signed consent was then
     obtained.  A preprocedure timeout was employed to verify the patient's
     identity and the planned biopsy site.
     
     Using sonographic localization, an appropriate spot on the skin was marked for
     the biopsy.  The area was then prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  Local anesthesia was achieved with 1% lidocaine.  Using continuous
     sonographic guidance, a single core biopsy of the liver was obtained with an
     18-gauge needle.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without any
     immediate post-procedure complications.  The specimen was immediately
     transported to pathology for further analysis.
     
     Conscious sedation was utilized, under continuous hemodynamic monitoring by
     the radiology nursing staff.
     
     Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 370**], the staff radiologist, was present and supervised the entire
     procedure.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Successful 18-gauge core biopsy of a transplant liver.

       58 year old man s/p liver tx, rising abd pain, fever

      r/o abscess, perf, etc.                                                         
     No contraindications for IV contrast
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     CLINICAL INDICATION:  Status-post liver transplant with abdominal pain and
     fever.
     
     TECHNIQUE:  Following the administration of intravenous and oral contrast,
     contiguous axial images were obtained from the lung bases thru the symphysis
     pubis.  The current study is compared to a prior examination dated [**3225-12-2**].
     Multiplanar reformatted images were created from the original data set.
     
     FINDINGS:  Evaluation of the lung bases demonstrates patchy consolidations
     within the right middle lobe, consistent with  pneumonia.  These appear
     unchanged from the prior examination.  No pleural or pericardial lesions are
     present.
     
     On the current examination, the liver is heterogeneous with several areas of
     triangular-shaped perfusion abnormalities.  These involve segments [**8-21**], parts
     of 6/7, as well as part of segment 4.  No focal parenchymal lesions are
     identified.  The portal vein, hepatic arteries, and hepatic veins appear
     widely patent.  Areas of low density are present adjacent to the main portal
     vein and its branches.  This is somewhat more prominent than on the prior
     examination, and may represent dilatation of the hepatic duct system and/or
     periportal edema. The triangular perfusion abnormalities which appear centered
     around the ductal system likely represents cholangitis in light of the normal-
     appearing vessels. As noted on the prior examination, there is a periportal
     fluid collection. It is stable in size, however, there is now mildly increased
     peripheral enhancement. Additionally, there is minimally increased fluid
     adjacent to the ligamentum teres.  If a biliary leak is suspected, a HIDA scan
     may be obtained for evaluation.  On the current examination, there is now a
     biliary duct stent. The posterior subphrenic fluid collection is unchanged in
     appearance.
     
     The pancreas, adrenal glands, and spleen are normal in appearance.  There is
     no evidence of hydronephrosis.  Multiple hypodense lesions are identified
     within the left kidney, the largest located in the upper pole, measures 1 cm
     in size.  A partially calcified cyst is present in the lower pole of the left
     kidney.
     
     Fluid within both the rectus abdominus muscles and adjacent stranding is
     unchanged in appearance.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3225-12-21**] 4:12 PM
     CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14975**]
     CT RECONSTRUCTION; CT 150CC NONIONIC CONTRAST
     Reason: r/o abscess, perf, etc.                                     
     Admitting Diagnosis: BILIARY STENOSCS
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     Oral contrast is noted about the small bowel without evidence of obstruction.
     The colon is unremarkable in appearance.  There is no free fluid in the
     abdomen or pelvis.  The distal ureters and bladder are unremarkable.
     
     Evaluation of the bone structures demonstrates no evidence of osteoblastic or
     lytic lesion.
     
     IMPRESSION
     
     1.  Pulmonary opacities consistent with pneumonia.
     2.  Interval placement of biliary stent.
     
     3.  Multiple perfusion abnormalities within the liver.  No vascular
         abnormalities are identified.  There is suggestion of increasing biliary
     ductal
         dilatation.  The perfusion abnormalities in assocaition with ductal
     represent cholangitis although there is no ductal wall enhancement.
     
     4.  Multiple renal lesions, unchanged in appearance.
     5.  Periportal fluid collection is stable in size, for biliary leak a HIDA
     scan could be performed.
     6.  Stable post-operative changes of the anterior abdominal wall.

     PTBD                                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14977**]
     Reason: please evaluate for potential PTC                           
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;BILE DUCT STENOSIS
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100CC
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47500 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA 74320 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA*
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p OLT [**3225-10-3**] c/b anastomotic stricture, s/p ERCP & stent 
      [**12-18**] - readmitted with elevated LFTS, AlkPhos
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please evaluate for potential PTC                                               
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     INDICATION:  A 59-year-old male status post orthotopic liver transplantation.
     MRCP performed on [**3225-12-18**] demonstrated multiple intrahepatic biliary
     strictures.  The findings were consistent with a preservation injury to the
     liver.  The patient now requires percutaneous biliary drainage.
     
     REFERRING PHYSICIAN:  [**Name10 (NameIs) 14978**] [**Name11 (NameIs) 7065**], MD
     
     RADIOLOGIST:  This procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**].  Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the attending radiologist, was present during the entire procedure. Dr.
     [**First Name (STitle) 1221**] reviewed the exam.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:
     
     The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the patient and an
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to the angiography
     suite and placed in supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in
     the standard sterile fashion.  At this time, a timeout was performed and
     proper identification of the patient and the procedure were confirmed.  Based
     on the findings of the MRCP, we decided to attempt a right-sided percutaneous
     biliary tube.  The attention was then turned to the right upper quadrant.
     Ultrasound and fluoroscopy were used to select the best spot for the puncture,
     which was deemed to be in the 11th intercostal space.  Local anesthesia was
     given in the area with lidocaine 1%.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 21-gauge
     Chiba needle was passed 3 times before opacification of the biliary tree was
     seen.  The biliary tree was dominant.  There was no evidence of intrahepatic
     biliary dilatation.  However, multiple stenosis throughout the biliary tree at
     multiple levels were seen in this small duct.  The common bile duct was normal
     and there was stent located within the common bile duct with the tip probably
     in the right hepatic duct and the other tip in the duodenum.  There was prompt
     emptying of contrast within the duodenum.  This suggests that the stent is
     working properly.  There was one slightly larger right hepatic duct; we then
     attempted to access this duct.
     
     After several attempts, we were able to produce the needle in that small right
     duct.  Contrast injected through the needle demonstrated opacification of the
     biliary tree.  However, we were unable to advance a wire through the biliary
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-7**] 8:02 AM
     PTBD                                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14977**]
     Reason: please evaluate for potential PTC                           
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;BILE DUCT STENOSIS
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100CC
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     (Cont)
     duct.  After this, we tried with at least 5 more unsuccessful attempts to
     introduce a wire through the biliary tree.
     
     These findings were discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 7065**], and at the time of
     interpretation, we decided to abort the procedure.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.  The patient tolerated
     the procedure well.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1)  Nondilated biliary tree with innumerable focal stenosis of very small
     biliary ducts.
     
     2)  There is prompt emptying of contrast into the duodenum in an antegrade
     fashion,  demonstrating that the biliary stent in the common bile duct is
     working.
     
     3) Unsuccessful attempt of percutaneous biliary drainage tube due to inability
     to advance the wire in very small bile duct.

     liver.  The patient now requires percutaneous biliary drainage.
     
     REFERRING PHYSICIAN:  [**Name10 (NameIs) 14978**] [**Name11 (NameIs) 7065**], MD
     
     RADIOLOGIST:  This procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**].  Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the attending radiologist, was present during the entire procedure. Dr.
     [**First Name (STitle) 1221**] reviewed the exam.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:
     
     The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the patient and an
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to the angiography
     suite and placed in supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in
     the standard sterile fashion.  At this time, a timeout was performed and
     proper identification of the patient and the procedure were confirmed.  Based
     on the findings of the MRCP, we decided to attempt a right-sided percutaneous
     biliary tube.  The attention was then turned to the right upper quadrant.
     Ultrasound and fluoroscopy were used to select the best spot for the puncture,
     which was deemed to be in the 11th intercostal space.  Local anesthesia was
     given in the area with lidocaine 1%.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 21-gauge
     Chiba needle was passed 3 times before opacification of the biliary tree was
     seen.  The biliary tree was dominant.  There was no evidence of intrahepatic
     biliary dilatation.  However, multiple stenosis throughout the biliary tree at
     multiple levels were seen in this small duct.  The common bile duct was normal
     and there was stent located within the common bile duct with the tip probably
     in the right hepatic duct and the other tip in the duodenum.  There was prompt
     emptying of contrast within the duodenum.  This suggests that the stent is
     working properly.  There was one slightly larger right hepatic duct; we then
     attempted to access this duct.
     
     After several attempts, we were able to produce the needle in that small right
     duct.  Contrast injected through the needle demonstrated opacification of the
     biliary tree.  However, we were unable to advance a wire through the biliary
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-7**] 8:02 AM
     PTBD                                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14977**]
     Reason: please evaluate for potential PTC                           
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;BILE DUCT STENOSIS
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100CC
     ______________________________________________________________________________

     (Cont)
     duct.  After this, we tried with at least 5 more unsuccessful attempts to
     introduce a wire through the biliary tree.
     
     These findings were discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 7065**], and at the time of
     interpretation, we decided to abort the procedure.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.  The patient tolerated
     the procedure well.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1)  Nondilated biliary tree with innumerable focal stenosis of very small
     biliary ducts.
     
     2)  There is prompt emptying of contrast into the duodenum in an antegrade
     fashion,  demonstrating that the biliary stent in the common bile duct is
     working.
     
     3) Unsuccessful attempt of percutaneous biliary drainage tube due to inability
     to advance the wire in very small bile duct.

     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT  47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47500 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY*
     * 75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74320 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,

     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple

     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.

     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.

     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT  47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47500 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY*
     * 75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74320 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,
