     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]

     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150

     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

5882,,,,3226-01-28 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"


     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT  47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47500 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY*
     * 75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74320 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and

     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.

     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the

     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.

     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.

     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.
     
     

",,

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT  47511 INTRO PERC TRNASHEPATIC STENT *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47500 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY*
     * 75982 CATH/STENT FOR INT/EXT BILIARY -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74320 PERC TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRA CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                    
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess ductal anatomy                                                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  59-year-male status post liver transplant.  The patient had a
     prior percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram, which demonstrated multiple
     intrahepatic strictures (PFC-like).  In the prior study we  were not able to
     introduce percutaneous biliary catheters due to very small nondilated ducts.
     At that time the patient had the ERCP stent.  The ERCP stent was removed and
     the patient returns for bilateral PTBD placement.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  This procedure was performed by Drs. [**Name5 (PTitle) 654**] & [**Doctor Last Name 319**], with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, present during the entire procedure.
     
     ANESTHESIA:  The procedure was performed under General Anesthesia by the
     anesthesiologist.  Approximately 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine was also injected into
     the site of the puncture for local anesthesia.
     
     CONSENT:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position.  The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed and proper identification of
     the patient and the procedure were confirmed. Local anesthesia was given with
     a total of 16 cc of 1% Lidocaine.  Initially, it was decided to attempt access
     through the right hepatic duct.  A 21-gauge Chiba needle was then inserted
     into the mid axillary line into the hepatic parenchyma.  The needle was
     withdrawn slowly with injection of contrast.  A bile duct was identified and
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     contrast was injected through the needle opacifying the biliary tree. However,
     the entrance site of the biliary was rather central, and it was decided to
     gain access in a more peripheral branch.  To secure this access, however, a
     0.018 Glidewire was introduced over the needle into the biliary tree and a
     needle was exchanged for a 3 French Accustick cannula.  With this, would be
     able to inject contrast at any time to opacify the biliary tree.  A right
     posterior duct was then chosen.  Using another 21-gauge Chiba needle, under
     fluoroscopic guidance, we were able to enter this right posterior duct
     peripherally with the needle.  A 0.018 Glidewire was was then advanced through
     the needle into the biliary tree.  It was then introduced more centrally,
     entering the common duct and eventually the duodenum.  The Chiba needle was
     then removed over the wire, and the 4 French Accustick system was then
     introduced over wire.  A 4 French Cobra catheter was introduced over the wire
     and placed in the duodenum.  The wire was exchanged for a Superstiff Amplatz
     wire.  The Accustick sheath was then removed, and a 7 French Bright-tip sheath
     was introduced over the wire and placed in the common duct.  The multiple
     strictures in the common duct and right main hepatic duct (please see Findings
     for a better description) were dilated using an 8 French x 4 cm balloon.
     
     Attention was then turned to the left side.  We were able to opacify the left
     hepatic duct with contrast from the right side.  Under fluoroscopic guidance,
     we were able to advance a 21-gauge Chiba needle into the left peripheral bile
     duct.  A 0.018 Glidewire was then advanced through the needle into the common
     duct and eventually into the duodenum.  The needle was exchanged for a 4
     French Accustick system.  Cobra catheter was advanced through the Accustick
     system over the wire and placed into the duodenum.  The wire was then
     exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff wire.  A 6 French Bright-tip sheath was
     then introduced over the wire. Antegrade cholangiogram was performed and
     multiple spot images were obtained (Findings described below). An 8-mm x 4-cm-
     long [**Hospital Unit Name **] LP balloon catheter was then introduced over the sheath and multiple
     strictures of the common duct and left hepatic duct were again dilated.
     
     After multiple dilatations of the biliary tree, it was decided to place
     bilateral 10 French biliary catheters.  They were introduced easily over the
     wires, and the pigtail device of both sides of the catheters was deployed into
     the duodenum.  Contrast was then injected through both biliary catheters and
     proper positioning was confirmed with the side holes within the biliary tree.
     The catheters were affixed to the skin using 0-Silk and a Stat-lock device.
     The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no complications.
     
     FINDINGS:  Bilateral antegrade cholangiograms were performed, demonstrating a
     mildly dilated biliary system.  There are innumerable strictures throughout
     the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.  The strictures in the main
     ducts were successfully dilated with an 8-mm balloon.  Final biliary catheter
     cholangiogram demonstrates the drains in adequate position.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-28**] 7:27 AM
     PTC                                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14983**]
     Reason: assess ductal anatomy                                       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     
     CONCLUSION:
     1) Multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic PFC-like biliary duct strictures.
     These are most likely related to the patient's history of preservation injury.
     
     2) Successful dilatation of multiple strictures in the right and left hepatic
     ducts and in common duct.
     
     3) Successful placement of bilateral 10 French Flexima biliary catheters.

     CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST                 Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14987**]
     Reason: please perform w/ only oral contrast.  assess for abcess    
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
     Field of view: 36
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        58 year old man s/p liver tx, rising abd pain, fever                          
              
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please perform w/ only oral contrast.  assess for abcess                        
     CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST:
      elevated Cr
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: Status post liver transplant with rising abdominal pain and fever,
     assess for abscess.
     
     COMPARISON: [**3225-12-21**]
     
     TECHNIQUE: Non-contrast MDCT axial images were obtained through the abdomen
     and pelvis, with coronal and sagittal reformations.  IV contrast was not
     given.
     
     CT ABDOMEN WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Again identified at the lung bases,
     there is bibasilar atelectasis and pleural effusions. There is diffuse ground
     glass opacity, greater on the right, which is largely unchanged from the prior
     study.  No paracardial fluid is seen.  We cannot assess the patency of the
     portal vein, hepatic arteries, and hepatic veins on this non-contrast study.
     Again identified are small low density fluid collections in the subhepatic
     space adjacent to the ligamentus teres and in the left subhepatic recess,
     which measure 2.2 x 2.5 and 1.4 x 1.4 cm respectively, which decreased in size
     from the prior study.  There remains mild diffuse fat stranding in the
     subhepatic recess.  There is no evidence of increasing fluid collection or
     abscess.  Additionally, there is subphrenic fluid collection, which appears to
     have decreased in size slightly from the prior study, and now measures
     approximately 3.6 x 5.8 cm.  Unchanged anterior abdominal wall fat stranding,
     consistent with post operative changes.  Interval placement of percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary stent.
     
     The pancreas, adrenal glands and spleen are unremarkable.  The previously
     described renal cysts are not well appreciated on this non-contrast study.  A
     partially calcified cyst in the lower pole of the left kidney is again seen.
     
     CT PELVIS WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:  Oral contrast is seen to flow
     distally through to the rectum.  No signs of obstruction.  Sigmoid colon is
     unremarkable.  There is no free fluid within the pelvis.  The bladder is
     unremarkable.  Bony structures demonstrate no obvious abnormality.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Decreasing size of subhepatic and posterior subphrenic fluid collections
     as described above.  No evidence of abscess.
     2)  Interval placement of percutaneous transhepatic biliary stent.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-29**] 2:30 PM

     pneumonia.  Bibasilar atelectasis and small pleural effusions.
     4)  Tiny, partially calcified left renal cyst.
     5)  Unchanged appearance of post operative changes of the anterior abdominal

     there is bibasilar atelectasis and pleural effusions. There is diffuse ground
     glass opacity, greater on the right, which is largely unchanged from the prior
     study.  No paracardial fluid is seen.  We cannot assess the patency of the
     portal vein, hepatic arteries, and hepatic veins on this non-contrast study.
     Again identified are small low density fluid collections in the subhepatic
     space adjacent to the ligamentus teres and in the left subhepatic recess,
     which measure 2.2 x 2.5 and 1.4 x 1.4 cm respectively, which decreased in size
     from the prior study.  There remains mild diffuse fat stranding in the
     subhepatic recess.  There is no evidence of increasing fluid collection or
     abscess.  Additionally, there is subphrenic fluid collection, which appears to
     have decreased in size slightly from the prior study, and now measures
     approximately 3.6 x 5.8 cm.  Unchanged anterior abdominal wall fat stranding,
     consistent with post operative changes.  Interval placement of percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary stent.
     
     The pancreas, adrenal glands and spleen are unremarkable.  The previously
     described renal cysts are not well appreciated on this non-contrast study.  A
     partially calcified cyst in the lower pole of the left kidney is again seen.
     
     CT PELVIS WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:  Oral contrast is seen to flow
     distally through to the rectum.  No signs of obstruction.  Sigmoid colon is
     unremarkable.  There is no free fluid within the pelvis.  The bladder is
     unremarkable.  Bony structures demonstrate no obvious abnormality.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Decreasing size of subhepatic and posterior subphrenic fluid collections
     as described above.  No evidence of abscess.
     2)  Interval placement of percutaneous transhepatic biliary stent.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-1-29**] 2:30 PM

     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
     Field of view: 36
     ______________________________________________________________________________

     (Cont)
     3)  Persisting patchy ground glass opacity, possibly consistent with
     pneumonia.  Bibasilar atelectasis and small pleural effusions.
     4)  Tiny, partially calcified left renal cyst.
     5)  Unchanged appearance of post operative changes of the anterior abdominal
     wall.

     DATE: [**3226-2-4**] 10:38 AM
     PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14989**]
     Reason: please place asap. thanks                                   
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 36569 PICC W/O [**State/Zipcode 802**] FLUOR GUID PLCT/REPLCT/REMOVE *
     * 76937 US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS        C1751 CATH [**Last Name (LF) 313**],[**First Name3 (LF) **]/CENT/MID(NOT D*
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx with malnutrition                                  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please place asap. thanks                                                       
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY: Status post liver transplant with malnutrition. Place double lumen
     PICC for TPN.
     
     PHYSICIANS: The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 251**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 294**]
     d'Othee. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**] [**Name (STitle) 295**], the attending physician, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] present and
     supervising throughout.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS: The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.
     The left upper arm was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
     Because no suitable superficial veins were visible, ultrasound was used for
     localization of a suitable vein. The brachial vein was patent and
     compressible. After local anesthesia with 2 cc of 1% Lidocaine, the brachial
     vein was entered under ultrasonographic guidance with a 21 gauge needle. Hard
     copies of ultrasound images were obtained, documenting patent vein before and
     after establishing an access. 0.018 guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy
     into the superior vena cava. Based on markers on the guidewire, it was
     determined that a length of 39 cm would be suitable. The PICC line was trimmed
     to length and advanced over a 4 French introducer sheath under fluoroscopic
     guidance into the superior vena cava. The sheath was removed and the catheter
     was flushed. A final chest x ray demonstrated the tip to be in the superior
     vena cava. The line is ready for use. A Stat-Lock was applied and the line was
     Hep locked. There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION: Successful placement of 39 cm long, dual lumen left sided PICC
     line with tip in the superior vena cava. The line is ready for use.

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains                                  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess for clogged ptc tubes                                                    
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  This is a 59 year old male status post liver transplant.  This
     was complicated by multiple intra- and extrahepatic biliary strictures,
     supposedly due to preservation injury.  The patient had bilateral PTBDs placed
     on [**3225-1-27**].  At this time, multiple strictures were dilated with an
     8-mm balloon.  Now in the last couple of days, there is decrease in the
     drainage of the biliary catheters.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 251**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 156**], the Attending Radiologist, present
     and supervising the entire procedure.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  After prepping the tubes in the usual sterile fashion,
     approximately 60 cc of contrast was injected through the bilateral PTBDs and a
     tube cholangiogram was performed. This demonstrates that both drains are
     patent without evidence of obstruction. There are again noted multiple
     intrahepatic biliary strictures. There is interval decrease in the biliary
     duct dilatation. Now there is no evidence of biliary duct dilatation. The
     common duct is very irregular. Contrast flows around the catheter with prompt
     emptying into the duodenum.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1) Both biliary drains are patent without evidence of obstruction.
     2) Interval decrease in the biliary duct dilatation.
     3) Innumerable intrahepatic biliary ductal strictures are unchanged when
     compared with the prior study.

     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 50
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains                                  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess for clogged ptc tubes                                                    
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  This is a 59 year old male status post liver transplant.  This
     was complicated by multiple intra- and extrahepatic biliary strictures,
     supposedly due to preservation injury.  The patient had bilateral PTBDs placed
     on [**3225-1-27**].  At this time, multiple strictures were dilated with an
     8-mm balloon.  Now in the last couple of days, there is decrease in the
     drainage of the biliary catheters.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 251**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 156**], the Attending Radiologist, present
     and supervising the entire procedure.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  After prepping the tubes in the usual sterile fashion,
     approximately 60 cc of contrast was injected through the bilateral PTBDs and a
     tube cholangiogram was performed. This demonstrates that both drains are
     patent without evidence of obstruction. There are again noted multiple
     intrahepatic biliary strictures. There is interval decrease in the biliary
     duct dilatation. Now there is no evidence of biliary duct dilatation. The
     common duct is very irregular. Contrast flows around the catheter with prompt
     emptying into the duodenum.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1) Both biliary drains are patent without evidence of obstruction.
     2) Interval decrease in the biliary duct dilatation.
     3) Innumerable intrahepatic biliary ductal strictures are unchanged when
     compared with the prior study.

     47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING CATHETER; 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPERATIVE PERIOD
     -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE; 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM
     NON-IONIC LESS THAN 100CC
     Reason: assess for drain location, r/o obstruction                  
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
       59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                   
       
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      assess for drain location, r/o obstruction                                      
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  Status post liver transplant with elevated LFT's and decreased
     biliary drainage output.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to
     the patient, and informed, written consent was obtained.  The patient was
     brought to the angiography suite, and placed supine on the table.  A pre-
     procedural time out was performed confirming the patient's identity and the
     procedure to be undertaken.
     
     Both PTBD's were prepped in the usual sterile fashion.  Approximately 40 cc of
     Optiray was injected through both PTBDs via slow hand injection.  Both PTBDs
     were in proper position, and both drains were patent without evidence of
     obstruction.  Again seen are multiple intrahepatic biliary strictures,
     unchanged from [**3226-2-6**].  There is no evidence of biliary duct dilatation.
     Contrast flowed freely from the intrahepatic biliary system through and around
     the drainage catheters, and into the small bowel.
     
     IMPRESSION:  No significant interval change from [**3226-2-6**].  Both PTBDs are
     patent without evidence of obstruction, and are in good position.  Unchanged
     innumerable intrahepatic biliary duct strictures.
     
     These findings were discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1651**] upon completion of the
     examination on [**3226-2-9**].

     DATE: [**3226-2-10**] 2:53 PM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14993**]
     Reason: R tube laeaking, L tube clogged -may need tube change       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 30CC
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                                                       *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx                                                  
         
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      R tube laeaking, L tube clogged -may need tube change                           
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: This is a 59-year-old male status post liver transplant. This is
     complicated by preservation issue of the bile duct and multiple strictures
     throughout the bile ducts. Patient was submitted to bilateral PTBDs. Now the
     right tube is leaking, and the left tube is clogged.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: This procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 156**]. Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**], the attending radilogist, was present during the entire procedure.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Approximately 15 cc of 1% lidocaine was administered in sites of
     the tubes. The patient also received 50 mg of fentanyl and 2 mg of Versed.
     
     CONSENT: The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE: The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position. The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion. The preparation included drainage. At this time, a preprocedure
     timeout was performed and proper identification of the patient and the
     procedure was confirmed. Approximately 10 cc of nonionic IV contrast was
     injected through the left drain and a tube cholangiogram was performed which
     demonstrated good position of the drain with good drainage. There was no
     evidence of flow obstruction or malpositioning. There was no evidence of leak.
     
     The attention was then turned to the right drain. Approximately 15 cc of
     nonionic IV contrast was injected through the right drain. The right drain was
     malpositioned, and there was a side hole located probably outside of the
     biliary tree which was leaking. We then decided to exchange the tube to a new
     8 Fr biliary tube. Biliary tube was then cut and the pigtail device was
     released. [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 129**] wire was introduced through the tube and positioned within
     the duodenum. The tube was removed over the wire. A new 8 Fr biliary tube was
     then introduced. The pigtail device was deployed. The tube was fixed to the
     skin using 0 Prolene. Approximately 5 cc of nonionic IV contrast was injected,
     demonstrating good position of the tube with prompt drainage into the
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-2-10**] 2:53 PM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14993**]
     Reason: R tube laeaking, L tube clogged -may need tube change       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 30CC
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     duodenum. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
     complications. Padlock devices were placed to secure the drains bilaterally.
     Sterile dressing was applied.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1. Leak in the right biliary drain. The drain was then exchanged by a new 8 Fr
     biliary drain which is in good position.
     2. The left drain is now in position without evidence of obstruction or leak.
     
     
     

",,

     complicated by preservation issue of the bile duct and multiple strictures
     throughout the bile ducts. Patient was submitted to bilateral PTBDs. Now the
     right tube is leaking, and the left tube is clogged.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: This procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 654**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 156**]. Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**], the attending radilogist, was present during the entire procedure.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Approximately 15 cc of 1% lidocaine was administered in sites of
     the tubes. The patient also received 50 mg of fentanyl and 2 mg of Versed.
     
     CONSENT: The risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed with the
     patient and informed consent was obtained.
     
     PROCEDURE: The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed in
     supine position. The abdomen was prepped and draped in the standard sterile
     fashion. The preparation included drainage. At this time, a preprocedure
     timeout was performed and proper identification of the patient and the
     procedure was confirmed. Approximately 10 cc of nonionic IV contrast was
     injected through the left drain and a tube cholangiogram was performed which
     demonstrated good position of the drain with good drainage. There was no
     evidence of flow obstruction or malpositioning. There was no evidence of leak.
     
     The attention was then turned to the right drain. Approximately 15 cc of
     nonionic IV contrast was injected through the right drain. The right drain was
     malpositioned, and there was a side hole located probably outside of the
     biliary tree which was leaking. We then decided to exchange the tube to a new
     8 Fr biliary tube. Biliary tube was then cut and the pigtail device was
     released. [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 129**] wire was introduced through the tube and positioned within
     the duodenum. The tube was removed over the wire. A new 8 Fr biliary tube was
     then introduced. The pigtail device was deployed. The tube was fixed to the
     skin using 0 Prolene. Approximately 5 cc of nonionic IV contrast was injected,
     demonstrating good position of the tube with prompt drainage into the
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-2-10**] 2:53 PM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14993**]
     Reason: R tube laeaking, L tube clogged -may need tube change       
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 30CC
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     duodenum. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
     complications. Padlock devices were placed to secure the drains bilaterally.
     Sterile dressing was applied.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1. Leak in the right biliary drain. The drain was then exchanged by a new 8 Fr
     biliary drain which is in good position.
     2. The left drain is now in position without evidence of obstruction or leak.

     INDICATION:  Feeding tube place by endoscopy today.  Check placement of post
     pyloric feeding tube.
     
     FINDINGS:  A single supine radiograph of the abdomen is provided.  Left and
     right sided biliary tubes are in place.  There is a catheter which appears to
     extend through the stomach and duodenum and then terminate within the jejunum.
     The bowel gas pattern is unremarkable.
     
     IMPRESSION:  The tip of the feeding tube overlies the expected location of the
     jejunum. Please note that the tube was not injected with contrast to confirm
     tube placement in the bowel lumen.

     DATE: [**3226-2-24**] 4:47 PM
     CHEST (PA & LAT)                                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14996**]
     Reason: Patient is febrile, poss. effusion                          
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
         58 year old man with cough and low-grade fever.                              
                  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Patient is febrile, poss. effusion                                              
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     TYPE OF EXAMINATION:  Chest PA and lateral.
     
     INDICATION:  Febrile patient with cough.  Evaluate chest.
     
     FINDINGS:
     
     AP and lateral view of the chest have been obtained with the patient in semi-
     erect position.  The patient was unable to follow breathing instructions. The
     films are analyzed in direct comparison with the preceding portable chest
     examination dated [**3226-2-5**].  It is understood that the patient is
     status post liver transplant.  An NG tube is noted, and apparently unchanged
     in position reaching far below the diaphragm.  A left subclavian approach
     central venous line is noted terminating overlying the SVC at the level of the
     carina.  There is no pneumothorax.  The heart size is within normal limits,
     considering AP technique.  No pulmonary vascular congestion is present.  There
     exist, however, multiple patchy infiltrates in both lungs present in the right
     lung mid field and bilaterally in the lower lung fields.  The pleural spaces
     are free, and the same holds for the posterior pleural sinuses on the lateral
     view.
     
     Comparing the pulmonary infiltrates with the findings on the previous
     examination is somewhat difficult as the exposure techniques of these films
     differ considerably.  It is however quite clear that the patchy infiltrates
     have progressed from what was present on the previous examination.  Review of
     a more remote examination of [**3226-1-8**] demonstrated already the
     presence of some infiltrates in similar location; however, they have
     undoubtedly increased.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     Progressing pulmonary infiltrates compatible with atypical pneumonitis.
     

",,

     DATE: [**3226-2-27**] 7:59 AM
     PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 14997**]
     Reason: pt pulled out his picc line.                                
     Admitting Diagnosis: LIVER TRANSPLANT;ELEVATED LFTS;MALNUTRITION
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 36569 PICC W/O PORT                  79 UNRELATED PROCEDURE/SERVICE DURIN*
     * 75998 FLUOR GUID PLCT/REPLCT/REMOVE  76937 US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS       *
     * C1751 CATH [**Last Name (LF) 313**],[**First Name3 (LF) **]/CENT/MID(NOT D                                     *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
       59 year old man s/p liver tx with malnutrition                                 
       
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt pulled out his picc line.                                                    
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59 year-old man status post liver transplant with malnutrition
     requiring dual-lumen PICC for long-term IV antibiotics.
     
     PROCEDURE AND FINDINS:  The procedure is performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 329**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 156**]
     (the Attending Radiologist) who was present and supervising throughout.  The
     patient's right upper arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.
     After infusion of 1% Lidocaine the right brachial vein was accessed under
     ultrasonographic guidance with a 21-gauge needle.  Hardcopy ultrasound images
     were obtained before and after access.  An 018 wire was advanced into the SVC
     under flouroscopic guidance . Based on the marker on the guidewire it was
     determined that a length of 30 cm would be appropriate for the dual-lumen
     PICC.  The PICC was cut to fit and advanced over a 5-French introducer sheath.
     The wire and sheath were removed. The line was flushed and heplocked and
     secured with a statlock.  A final chest image demonstrated appropriate
     positioning of the PICC tip in the SVC.  The patient tolerated the procedure
     well and there were no immediate postprocedure complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of right 30 cm total length dual-lumen PICC
     via brachial vein access with tip in SVC.  Line is ready for use.

     HISTORY:  59 year-old man status post liver transplant with malnutrition
     requiring dual-lumen PICC for long-term IV antibiotics.
     
     PROCEDURE AND FINDINS:  The procedure is performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 329**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 156**]
     (the Attending Radiologist) who was present and supervising throughout.  The
     patient's right upper arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.
     After infusion of 1% Lidocaine the right brachial vein was accessed under
     ultrasonographic guidance with a 21-gauge needle.  Hardcopy ultrasound images
     were obtained before and after access.  An 018 wire was advanced into the SVC
     under flouroscopic guidance . Based on the marker on the guidewire it was
     determined that a length of 30 cm would be appropriate for the dual-lumen
     PICC.  The PICC was cut to fit and advanced over a 5-French introducer sheath.
     The wire and sheath were removed. The line was flushed and heplocked and
     secured with a statlock.  A final chest image demonstrated appropriate
     positioning of the PICC tip in the SVC.  The patient tolerated the procedure
     well and there were no immediate postprocedure complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of right 30 cm total length dual-lumen PICC
     via brachial vein access with tip in SVC.  Line is ready for use.

     [**Last Name (un) 1424**]-INTESTINAL TUBE PLACEMENT (W/[**Last Name (un) 14985**]); 79 UNRELATED PROCEDURE/SERVICE DURING POSTOPERATIVE PERIODClip # [**Telephone/Fax (1) 15007**]

     Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOGLYCEMIA;ALTERED MENTAL STATUS;TELEMETRY
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 y.o. male s/p liver tx with poor po intake                                 
         
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please place feeding tube post pyloric                                          
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  A 59-year-old man status post liver transplant with poor p.o.
     intake.
     
     PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 329**], [**First Name3 (LF) 1278**], and [**Doctor Last Name 1746**].  The patient was
     placed supine on the fluoroscopy table.  After coating the 12 French feeding
     tube with lidocaine jelly, the tube was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance
     into the stomach.  The wire was withdrawn and 5 cc of contrast and 30 cc of
     air were administered to elucidate the location of the pylorus.  After
     reinserting the wire, the tube was advanced through the pylorus into the
     duodenum.  The tube was advanced to its tip at the level of the ligament of
     Treitz.  The wire was withdrawn and additional injection of 5 cc of contrast
     demonstrated appropriate positioning of the tube tip at the distal
     duodenum/proximal jejunum.  The tube was secured with tape.  The patient
     tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post- procedure
     complications.
     
     IMPRESSION: Successful placement of 12 French enteric feeding tube with tip at
     the level of the ligament of Treitz.

     is interval worsening of the heterogeneity of the liver parenchyma.  The main
     hepatic artery, right and left hepatic arteries are patent.  The main portal
     vein is patent.  There is a thrombosis of the right anterior branch of the
     portal vein.  However, this finding is unchanged when compared to CT from
     [**3225-12-21**].  The left portal vein and the right posterior branch are
     patent.  There is no intrahepatic bile duct dilatation.

     parenchymal disease.

     when compared to [**3226-12-21**].

     portal vein are patent.

     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      eval for obstruction                                                            
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     PROCEDURE DATE:  [**3226-3-18**].
     
     HISTORY:  59 year old male status post liver transplant with elevated liver
     function tests.  Please perform cholangiography with possible catheter
     repositioning.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1057**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2658**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the staff radiologist, was present and supervising
     throughout.  Given the patient's mental status and the inability to locate the
     health care proxy, consent was implied.  The urgency and indications for the
     procedure were documented in the patient's chart prior to the start of the
     procedure.  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.  His
     abdomen, including the bilateral biliary drainage catheters, was prepped and
     draped in the standard sterile fashion.  A fluoroscopic spot film of the
     abdomen was obtained, demonstrating the bilateral biliary drainage catheters
     to be appropriately positioned as compared with the previous examination.
     Through the right 8 French biliary drainage catheter, a cholangiogram was
     performed via hand injection of nonionic contrast.  This demonstrated a
     nondilated biliary tree with free and rapid passage of contrast into the bowel
     lumen beyond surgical anastomosis. Of note, blood clots were noted within the
     biliary tree. Some clots and blood stained bile could be aspirated. The
     contrast was then aspirated and our attention was turned to the left hepatic
     biliary drain.
     
     A tube cholangiogram was performed via hand injection of nonionic contrast
     through the indwelling left 8 French biliary drainage catheter.  This
     demonstrated the left hepatic drainage catheter to be in good position with no
     evidence of ductal dilatation.  Overall, these findings are unchanged from the
     previous study dated [**3226-2-20**].  After the cholangiogram was performed,
     the catheters were placed to external bag drainage.  Dry sterile dressings
     were applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS:  None.
     
     CONTRAST:  30 cc of 60% Optiray.
                                                                 (Over)

     IMPRESSION:  Tube cholangiography demonstrated the indwelling bilateral 8
     French biliary drainage catheters to be in adequate position.  There was no
     evidence of intrahepatic ductal dilatation with free and rapid passage of
     contrast into the bowel lumen.  Overall, these findings remain unchanged
     compared to the previous study dated [**3226-2-20**].Incidental note of blood
     stained bile with intraluminal clots in the common duct, the cause for which
     is uncertain.
     
     These findings were discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1650**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1651**] from the Transplant
     Surgery Service at the time of the procedure.
