     LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN); -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICEClip # [**Telephone/Fax (1) 15009**]
     DUPLEX DOPP ABD/PEL
     Reason: rising bilirubin.  rule out HA thrombosis                   
     Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOGLYCEMIA;ALTERED MENTAL STATUS;TELEMETRY
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
       58M with rising LFT's s/p liver transplant 2 months ago                        
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      rising bilirubin.  rule out HA thrombosis                                       
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  58 year old male status post liver transplant two months ago. Now
     with rising LFTs.
     
     COMPARISONS:  Comparison is made to [**3226-1-26**].
     
     LIVER ULTRASOUND:  The liver echo texture is coarse and heterogeneous.  There
     is interval worsening of the heterogeneity of the liver parenchyma.  The main
     hepatic artery, right and left hepatic arteries are patent.  The main portal
     vein is patent.  There is a thrombosis of the right anterior branch of the
     portal vein.  However, this finding is unchanged when compared to CT from
     [**3225-12-21**].  The left portal vein and the right posterior branch are
     patent.  There is no intrahepatic bile duct dilatation.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1. Interval worsening of the heterogeneity of the liver echotexture suggests
     parenchymal disease.
     2. Thrombosis of the right anterior branch of the portal vein is unchanged
     when compared to [**3226-12-21**].
     3. The main portal vein, left portal vein, and right posterior branch of the
     portal vein are patent.
     4. The hepatic artery is patent.

     74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM; 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING CATHETERClip # [**Telephone/Fax (1) 15008**]
     78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPERATIVE PERIOD; 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING CATHETER
     78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPERATIVE PERIOD; -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE
     74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM; -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE
     NON-IONIC LESS THAN 100CC
     Reason: eval for obstruction                                        
     Admitting Diagnosis: HYPOGLYCEMIA;ALTERED MENTAL STATUS;TELEMETRY
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 30
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains   with rising alk phos & t bil 
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      eval for obstruction                                                            
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     PROCEDURE DATE:  [**3226-3-18**].
     
     HISTORY:  59 year old male status post liver transplant with elevated liver
     function tests.  Please perform cholangiography with possible catheter
     repositioning.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1057**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2658**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the staff radiologist, was present and supervising
     throughout.  Given the patient's mental status and the inability to locate the
     health care proxy, consent was implied.  The urgency and indications for the
     procedure were documented in the patient's chart prior to the start of the
     procedure.  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.  His
     abdomen, including the bilateral biliary drainage catheters, was prepped and
     draped in the standard sterile fashion.  A fluoroscopic spot film of the
     abdomen was obtained, demonstrating the bilateral biliary drainage catheters
     to be appropriately positioned as compared with the previous examination.
     Through the right 8 French biliary drainage catheter, a cholangiogram was
     performed via hand injection of nonionic contrast.  This demonstrated a
     nondilated biliary tree with free and rapid passage of contrast into the bowel
     lumen beyond surgical anastomosis. Of note, blood clots were noted within the
     biliary tree. Some clots and blood stained bile could be aspirated. The
     contrast was then aspirated and our attention was turned to the left hepatic
     biliary drain.
     
     A tube cholangiogram was performed via hand injection of nonionic contrast
     through the indwelling left 8 French biliary drainage catheter.  This
     demonstrated the left hepatic drainage catheter to be in good position with no
     evidence of ductal dilatation.  Overall, these findings are unchanged from the
     previous study dated [**3226-2-20**].  After the cholangiogram was performed,
     the catheters were placed to external bag drainage.  Dry sterile dressings
     were applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS:  None.
     
     CONTRAST:  30 cc of 60% Optiray.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-3-18**] 3:41 PM

     then advanced under fluoroscopic guidance through the pylorus and into the
     duodenum.  The tube tip was positioned in the proximal jejunum.  Post
     placement injection of conray demonstrated appropriate positioning of the tube
     tip past the ligament of Treitz in the proximal jejunum.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of nasojejunal feeding tube.

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around
      exit site.
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-24**] 6:49 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15019**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-24**] 6:49 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15019**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

",,

     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around
      exit site.
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-24**] 6:49 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15019**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

      assess for infiltrate

     COMPARISON:  [**3226-4-16**].
     
     INDICATION:  Fever.  Status post liver transplantation.
     
     The heart demonstrates left ventricular configuration.  The mediastinal and
     hilar contours are within normal limits for low lung volumes and portable
     technique.  Again, demonstrated is a bilateral interstitial pattern with
     poorly defined reticular and nodular opacities predominantly in the lung
     periphery.  Direct comparison is somewhat limited due to differences in
     technique between the two studies, but there has been a possible slight
     interval increase.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Peripheral reticular and nodular opacities with apparent slight
     interval increase compared to the previous study, concerning for worsening
     atypical infection.  Differential diagnosis includes a post-transplant
     lymphoproliferative disorder.

     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around
      exit site.
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-24**] 6:49 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15019**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

",,

     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P

     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************

     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            NON-IONIC LESS THAN 100CC           *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around
      exit site.
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-24**] 6:49 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15019**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

",,

     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right P
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire, a separate #7 French bright tipped angiographic sheath was
     advanced.  After the inner dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was
     performed.  Again was noted ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of
     dilation or stricture within the left hepatic ducts.  The 7 French sheath was
     then removed and a new 8 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage
     catheter was advanced until the tip was within the Roux limb.  After the
     [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed, the catheter pigtail was formed and locked.  The
     catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin using a
     0 silk suture.  A dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     At this time, the 7 French sheath was removed from the right hepatic duct and
     a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter was
     advanced over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire into the Roux limb.  The [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was then
     removed and the catheter pigtail was formed and locked, with the tip
     appropriately positioned beyond the surgical anastomosis within the Roux limb.
     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin
     using a 0 silk suture.  A separate dry sterile dressing was applied.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.
     
     MEDICATIONS: 1 percent lidocaine.  Three grams of intravenous Unasyn. 1.5 mg
     of Versed and 50 mcg of fentanyl were administered in intermittent doses with
     continuous monitoring of vital signs by the nursing staff.
     
     CONTRAST:  40 cc of full strength Optiray 320.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     
     1.  Pull-back cholangiography revealed no evidence of biliary dilatation or
     stricture within the hepatic ducts bilaterally.  There is free and rapid
     passage of contrast beyond the surgical anastomosis into the Roux limb.
     
     2.  Replacement of a new 8 French drainage catheter via the left hepatic duct
     along with upsizing for a new 10 French biliary drainage catheter via the
     right hepatic duct.  Both catheters were capped for internal drainage.

     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *

     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            NON-IONIC LESS THAN 100CC           *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
        59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around
      exit site.
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant in clinic today with leaking right PTC caTh. Needs to
      be upsized. Please also place stitch in left PTC. Pt with right and left PTC in
      place for biliary stenosis. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male status post liver transplant with bilateral biliary
     drains placed for bile duct stricture.  Patient presents for upsizing of the
     right drain with evaluation of both hepatic ducts.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1376**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1377**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 179**], the staff radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout.  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were
     discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained, the patient was
     placed supine on the angiography table.  His abdomen, including the biliary
     drainage catheters, were prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.
     Three grams of intravenous Unasyn was administered.  The skin and subcutaneous
     tissues surrounding the catheters was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film was obtained, demonstrating the catheters to be
     appropriately positioned.  In addition, a post-pyloric feeding tube is present
     within the bowel lumen. Each catheter was sequentially cut, releasing the
     locked pigtails and 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires were advanced through each of the
     indwelling catheter lumens into the Roux limb.  The indwelling catheters were
     removed.  Over the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire positioned in the right hepatic duct, a 7
     French bright tipped angiographic sheath was advanced.  After the inner
     dilator was removed, a pull-back cholangiogram was performed.  This revealed
     persistent ectasia of the common duct with no evidence of dilation in the
     right hepatic ducts.  No strictures were present.  There was free passage of
     contrast into the Roux limb beyond the surgical anastomosis.
     
     Our attention was then turned to the left biliary system.  Over the 0.035

     The catheter was capped for internal drainage and was secured to the skin

     DATE: [**3226-4-29**] 10:40 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15022**]
     Reason: please change lateral (Right) ptc for leaking at insertion s
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 60
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant                      
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please change lateral (Right) ptc for leaking at insertion site                 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     This report also refers to clip #[**Clip Number (Radiology) 15023**].
     
     HISTORY:  This is a 59-year-old man status post liver transplant presenting
     with poor p.o. intake and also right-sided leakage around percutaneous biliary
     drainage tube.
     
     RADIOLOGIST:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**] [**Name (STitle) 128**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1057**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2658**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**] reviewed the exam.
     
     CONSENT:  After receiving explanation of the benefits and risks of the
     procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient.
     
     TECHNIQUE:  With the patient sitting on a stretcher, local anesthetic spray
     and gel were used to anesthetize the nostril and oropharynx.  An 8-French
     nasal post-pyloric tube was then advanced through the right nostril.  The
     patient was then moved to the fluoroscopy table and the catheter was further
     advanced into the proximal jejunum under fluoroscopic guidance.  A final
     abdominal x-ray image was obtained documenting adequate position of the
     catheter.  Then, the right side of the abdomen and the indwelling biliary
     tubes were prepared in a sterile fashion.  Tube cholangiogram through the
     right biliary drainage catheter showed only opacification of the small bowel
     with no intrahepatic biliary ducts visualized.  The tube was slightly pulled
     back and good opacification of intrahepatic ducts was obtained.  These ducts
     did not appear dilated.  It was then realized that the leakage was probably
     due to the malposition of the tube which had side holes outside the
     intrahepatic biliary ducts.  A 0.035 [**Last Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through
     the tube into the small bowel.  The tube was removed and a new 10-French
     biliary drainage catheter with additional proximal side holes, created to
     provide drainage of the right hepatic lobe was advanced over the wire all the
     way into the small bowel.  The pigtail was formed into the small bowel and a
     new contrast injection documented adequate drainage and opacification of the
     intrahepatic biliary ducts.  The catheter was secured to the skin with 1-0
     silk stitch and the dressing was applied.
     
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-29**] 10:40 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15022**]
     Reason: please change lateral (Right) ptc for leaking at insertion s
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 60
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     COMPLICATIONS:  There are no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Successful placement of a post-pyloric feeding tube.
     2)  Successful exchange of a right-sided 10-French biliary drainage catheter
     for a new 10-French catheter with additional side holes.

     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant                      
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please change lateral (Right) ptc for leaking at insertion site                 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     This report also refers to clip #[**Clip Number (Radiology) 15023**].
     
     HISTORY:  This is a 59-year-old man status post liver transplant presenting
     with poor p.o. intake and also right-sided leakage around percutaneous biliary
     drainage tube.
     
     RADIOLOGIST:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**] [**Name (STitle) 128**] and Dr.
     [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1057**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2658**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2658**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**] reviewed the exam.
     
     CONSENT:  After receiving explanation of the benefits and risks of the
     procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient.
     
     TECHNIQUE:  With the patient sitting on a stretcher, local anesthetic spray
     and gel were used to anesthetize the nostril and oropharynx.  An 8-French
     nasal post-pyloric tube was then advanced through the right nostril.  The
     patient was then moved to the fluoroscopy table and the catheter was further
     advanced into the proximal jejunum under fluoroscopic guidance.  A final
     abdominal x-ray image was obtained documenting adequate position of the
     catheter.  Then, the right side of the abdomen and the indwelling biliary
     tubes were prepared in a sterile fashion.  Tube cholangiogram through the
     right biliary drainage catheter showed only opacification of the small bowel
     with no intrahepatic biliary ducts visualized.  The tube was slightly pulled
     back and good opacification of intrahepatic ducts was obtained.  These ducts
     did not appear dilated.  It was then realized that the leakage was probably
     due to the malposition of the tube which had side holes outside the
     intrahepatic biliary ducts.  A 0.035 [**Last Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through
     the tube into the small bowel.  The tube was removed and a new 10-French
     biliary drainage catheter with additional proximal side holes, created to
     provide drainage of the right hepatic lobe was advanced over the wire all the
     way into the small bowel.  The pigtail was formed into the small bowel and a
     new contrast injection documented adequate drainage and opacification of the
     intrahepatic biliary ducts.  The catheter was secured to the skin with 1-0
     silk stitch and the dressing was applied.
     
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-4-29**] 10:40 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15022**]
     Reason: please change lateral (Right) ptc for leaking at insertion s
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 60
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     COMPLICATIONS:  There are no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Successful placement of a post-pyloric feeding tube.
     2)  Successful exchange of a right-sided 10-French biliary drainage catheter
     for a new 10-French catheter with additional side holes.
     
     

",,

     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
       59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc    
                     
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      please assess lateral ptc. continues to leak at insertion site                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  Biliary stenosis status post liver transplant.  The lateral
     (right) drain continues to leak at the insertion site.
     
     PROCEDURE:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 7771**] [**Name (STitle) 7772**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**]
     [**Name (STitle) 128**] with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1543**] [**Name (STitle) 156**] present and supervising.  Risks and benefits
     of the procedure were explained to the patient and a written informed consent
     was obtained.  Initial scout examination revealed a right and left biliary
     drainage catheter in place.  30 cc of Optiray 320 was injected in the 10
     French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter.  It appears to be
     in good position with no evidence of contrast leak or stricture formation. The
     contrast flows freely into the Roux limb.
     
     Some slight swelling was noted at the insertion site of the right drainage
     catheter.  Upon ultrasound examination, there was a small amount of edema in
     the subcutaneous tissue without evidence of a focal collection.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Right biliary drain in good position without evidence of leak.
     2)  Small amount of subcutaneous edema at the insertion site of the right
     drainage catheter without evidence of a focal collection.

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
         59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around 
      exit site. please evaluate and upsize drain today.  any questions call [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] 
      [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      bile leak around right ptc.  needs to be upsized today!                         
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  Biliary stenosis status post liver transplant.  The lateral drain
     continues to leak at the insertion site.
     
     PROCEDURE:
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 179**] present and supervising the procedure.  After explaining the risks and
     benefits of the procedure to the patient, a written informed consent was
     obtained.  Initial scout examination demonstrated both right and left biliary
     drainage catheters in place.  20 cc of Optiray 320 was injected in the lateral
     10-French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter.  This catheter
     was seen to be in appropriate position with no evidence of contrast leak or
     stricture formation.  Free flow of contrast was seen into the Roux limb.  The
     catheter was left in place.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Cholangiogram demonstrating right biliary drain to be in good
     position without evidence of leak, free flow into the Roux limb.

                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION:  Biliary stenosis status post liver transplant.  The lateral drain
     continues to leak at the insertion site.
     
     PROCEDURE:
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 369**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 179**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 179**] present and supervising the procedure.  After explaining the risks and
     benefits of the procedure to the patient, a written informed consent was
     obtained.  Initial scout examination demonstrated both right and left biliary
     drainage catheters in place.  20 cc of Optiray 320 was injected in the lateral
     10-French percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage catheter.  This catheter
     was seen to be in appropriate position with no evidence of contrast leak or
     stricture formation.  Free flow of contrast was seen into the Roux limb.  The
     catheter was left in place.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Cholangiogram demonstrating right biliary drain to be in good
     position without evidence of leak, free flow into the Roux limb.

     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
          59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around  
      exit site. please evaluate and upsize drain today.  any questions call [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]  
      [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BOTH LEFT AND RIGHT 
      PTC TUBES.  IF EITHER OR  BOTH AREAS ARE DILATED PLEASE MAKE SURE THEY ARE 
      TREATED. AND PLEASE MAKE SURE THE RIGHT PTC TUBE IS CHANGED.  IF [**Doctor First Name **] HAVE ANY 
      QUESTIONS NOTIFY [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] IMMEDIATELY!!                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]
     Reason: patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BO
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,

     * 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *

     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *

     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
          59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around  
      exit site. please evaluate and upsize drain today.  any questions call [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]  
      [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BOTH LEFT AND RIGHT 
      PTC TUBES.  IF EITHER OR  BOTH AREAS ARE DILATED PLEASE MAKE SURE THEY ARE 
      TREATED. AND PLEASE MAKE SURE THE RIGHT PTC TUBE IS CHANGED.  IF [**Doctor First Name **] HAVE ANY 
      QUESTIONS NOTIFY [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] IMMEDIATELY!!                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]
     Reason: patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BO
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.

     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,
5882,,,,3226-05-08 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"

          59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around  
      exit site. please evaluate and upsize drain today.  any questions call [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]  
      [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BOTH LEFT AND RIGHT 
      PTC TUBES.  IF EITHER OR  BOTH AREAS ARE DILATED PLEASE MAKE SURE THEY ARE

                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]

     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]

      QUESTIONS NOTIFY [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] IMMEDIATELY!!                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]
     Reason: patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BO
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.

     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * 78 RELATED PROCEDURE DURING POSTOPER -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER                                      *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
          59 year old man s/p liver tx with 2 ptc drains-right draining bile around  
      exit site. please evaluate and upsize drain today.  any questions call [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]  
      [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BOTH LEFT AND RIGHT 
      PTC TUBES.  IF EITHER OR  BOTH AREAS ARE DILATED PLEASE MAKE SURE THEY ARE 
      TREATED. AND PLEASE MAKE SURE THE RIGHT PTC TUBE IS CHANGED.  IF [**Doctor First Name **] HAVE ANY 
      QUESTIONS NOTIFY [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] IMMEDIATELY!!                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]
     Reason: patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BO
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,

     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,
5882,,,,3226-05-08 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"
