                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

      TREATED. AND PLEASE MAKE SURE THE RIGHT PTC TUBE IS CHANGED.  IF [**Doctor First Name **] HAVE ANY 
      QUESTIONS NOTIFY [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] IMMEDIATELY!!                                  
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     HISTORY:  59-year-old male S/P liver transplant, with two BDC internal and
     external drainage catheters.  Bile leak around exit site of right draining
     tube.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS
     
     The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 862**] [**Name (STitle) 863**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3669**] [**Name (STitle) 15028**] with Dr.
     [**Last Name (STitle) 156**] Attending Radiologist presenting and supervising.  After explaining
     risks and benefits of the procedure to the patient a written informed consent
     was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
     area around the existing biliary drainage tubes was prepped and draped in
     standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed.  General
     endotracheal anesthesia was administered.
     
     A fluoroscopic spot film demonstrates the catheter to be appropriately
     positioned.  Both drainage catheters were cut at the hub, releasing the
     pigtail, and [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires advanced through each catheter into the Roux limb.
     The catheters were exchanged for a 6 French bright tip sheath with inner
     dilator.  The inner dilators were removed.  Pull back cholangiogram was
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-8**] 10:55 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15027**]
     Reason: patient has an elevated alk phos level.  NEED TO EVALUATE BO
     Admitting Diagnosis: S/P LIVER TRANSPLANT;SEPSIS;FEVER
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 80
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     performed through each sheath.  This revealed non-dilated biliary ductal
     system, with short segment stricture just proximal to the anastomosis. We
     advanced an 8 mm x 3 cm balloon across the area of stenosis through the right
     bright tip sheath, followed by dilatation of the stricture with an 8 mm
     balloon through the left sheath.  Subsequent cholangiogram demonstrated
     partial opening of this stricture.  We then decided to advance a 10 mm balloon
     through the left sheath, across the area of stenosis.  Our final cholangiogram
     demonstrated partial re-opening of the stenotic area.   The bright tip sheaths
     where then exchanged for a new 10 French percutaneous transhepatic biliary
     drainage catheter on the right and an 8 French catheter on the left.  After
     the [**Last Name (un) 129**] wire was removed with the inner plastic stiffener the catheter
     pigtail was formed and locked within the Roux loop.  The catheters were capped
     for internal drainage and secured to the skin using 0 silk sutures.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 15029**]
     sterile dressing was applied.  
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  None.  
     
     ANESTHESIA:  General
     
     IMPRESSION:  
     
     1. Moderate stenosis just proximal to the surgical anastomotic site, with free
     flow of contrast into the Roux loop.  Area of stenosis dilated with 8, and 10
     mm balloons, with some improvement in flow.  
     2. Exchange of existing right 10 French and left 8 French percutaneous
     transhepatic biliary drainage catheters for new 10 French catheter on the
     right, and 8 French catheter on the left.

     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * NON-IONIC 100 CC                                                         *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's in place. Right
      catheter leaking large amount of fluid areound cath site. Needs a tube check.
      Will need IV levo pre procuedure.
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: 59-year-old man who is status post orthotopic liver
     transplantation on [**3225-10-3**], with known multiple intra- and extrahepatic
     biliary duct strictures. The patient is status post bilateral placement of
     internal and external percutaneous transhepatic biliary drains (PTBD) since
     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1084**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1085**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 293**] [**Name (STitle) 294**] d'Othee.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**]
     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

",,

     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * NON-IONIC 100 CC                                                         *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's in place. Right
      catheter leaking large amount of fluid areound cath site. Needs a tube check.
      Will need IV levo pre procuedure.
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: 59-year-old man who is status post orthotopic liver
     transplantation on [**3225-10-3**], with known multiple intra- and extrahepatic
     biliary duct strictures. The patient is status post bilateral placement of
     internal and external percutaneous transhepatic biliary drains (PTBD) since
     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1084**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1085**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 293**] [**Name (STitle) 294**] d'Othee.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**]
     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

5882,,,,3226-05-21 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"


     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * NON-IONIC 100 CC                                                         *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's in place. Right
      catheter leaking large amount of fluid areound cath site. Needs a tube check.
      Will need IV levo pre procuedure.
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: 59-year-old man who is status post orthotopic liver
     transplantation on [**3225-10-3**], with known multiple intra- and extrahepatic
     biliary duct strictures. The patient is status post bilateral placement of
     internal and external percutaneous transhepatic biliary drains (PTBD) since
     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1084**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1085**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 293**] [**Name (STitle) 294**] d'Othee.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**]
     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

",,

     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * 74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM             -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     * NON-IONIC 100 CC                                                         *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's in place. Right
      catheter leaking large amount of fluid areound cath site. Needs a tube check.
      Will need IV levo pre procuedure.
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     INDICATION: 59-year-old man who is status post orthotopic liver
     transplantation on [**3225-10-3**], with known multiple intra- and extrahepatic
     biliary duct strictures. The patient is status post bilateral placement of
     internal and external percutaneous transhepatic biliary drains (PTBD) since
     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1084**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1085**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 293**] [**Name (STitle) 294**] d'Othee.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**]
     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

",,

     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1084**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1085**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 293**] [**Name (STitle) 294**] d'Othee.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 294**]
     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-5-21**] 7:18 AM
     CATH CHEK/REMV                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15030**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with biliary strictures and 2 PTC's 
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

",,

     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around

     (Cont)
     into the duodenum and biliary tube was removed and exchanged for a 7-French
     [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheath, the tip of which was placed in the duodenum. The same
     maneuver was repeated at the level of the left-sided access. Successive
     pullback cholangiograms were obtained on the right and then on the left side,
     by injecting contrast under fluoroscopy while pulling back slowly the 7-French
     sheaths. This showed two areas of focal narrowing located respectively in the
     mid portion of the CBD and in its distal portion, at the level of the ampulla.
     Just above and below the first stenosis (mid CBD), the caliber of the bile
     duct was relatively enlarged. A third area of narrowing was found at the hilum
     after further withdrawal of the [**Last Name (un) 296**]-Tip sheaths, and this involved the
     central portions of the right and left hepatic ducts.
     
     The 7-French sheath was readvanced with its dilator over the wire until its
     tip reached the duodenum, and dilator and 0.035 wire were removed. An 8 mm
     diameter cutting balloon was then advanced through the sheath and balloon
     dilation was performed serially along the bile ducts for periods of 1 minute
     at a pressure of 8 atmospheres.
     
     Control cholangiogram from each side showed rapid passage of contrast from the
     bile ducts into the duodenum. The 7-French sheaths were then exchanged over
     0.035 [**Last Name (un) 129**] wires for new PTBD tubes, similar as before (10-French on the
     right side and 8-French on the left side). These internal and external tubes
     were kept for internal drainage and were sutured to the skin using 0 Prolene.
     They were also affixed to the skin with StatLock. Dressings were applied on
     both sides. The pigtails of the catheters are in the duodenum and their
     proximal side holes are in the intrahepatic bile ducts above the hepatic
     hilum.
     
     COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications occurred.
     
     MEDICATIONS: Total of 10 mL of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia
     subcutaneously. Total of 75 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were given in
     divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic monitoring during the
     procedure. Levoquin was given intravenously before starting the procedure. The
     patient also received premedications on the floor before the procedure. Total
     of 130 mL of Optiray 320 (nonionic contrast).
     
     CONCLUSION: Bile duct dilatation with an 8 mm cutting balloon. Bilateral PTBD
     tubes were replaced, same as before (10-French on the right and 8-French on
     the left).

",,

     INDICATION: 59-year-old man who is status post orthotopic liver

     biliary duct strictures. The patient is status post bilateral placement of
     internal and external percutaneous transhepatic biliary drains (PTBD) since
     [**3226-1-28**], and status post balloon dilation to 10 mm diameter on [**3226-5-8**]
     at the level of the common bile duct. Persistent, abundant bile leak around
     the right-sided PTBD.

     [**Name (STitle) 295**], the staff radiologist, was present for the entire procedure.
     
     TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent had been obtained prior to the
     procedure. The patient was placed supine on the table and his right and left
     PTBD tubes and surrounding skin were draped and prepped using sterile
     technique. A scout view of the right upper quadrant was first obtained,
     showing proper positioning of the bilateral biliary drains. Contrast was then
     injected successively in the left and right PTBD tubes with tube
     cholangiograms showing unchanged appearance of the intra and extrahepatic bile
     ducts as compared to the last examinations, with small, narrowed intrahepatic
     ducts and a common bile duct (CBD) of variable caliber. There was rapid
     passage of contrast from the CBD into the duodenum, where the pigtails of both
     biliary drains were located.
     
     Then, a 0.035 [**Name (STitle) 129**] guidewire was advanced through the right-sided PTBD tube

     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                                                       *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic caths in place. Last
      study done on [**5-21**] which revealed 3 stenosis that were ballooned and caths were
      replaed with same size (10F on right and 8Fr on left). Pt has continued copius
      amts of leakage around right catheter. please do cholangio and pull back
      cholangiogram and balloon dilatation if needed. 
      Will upsizing of right catheter help stop leakage around exit site?
      Pt will need IV levo pre procedure. Please call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 342**] with results of
      study. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     HISTORY:  This is a 59-year-old man with biliary stenosis status post liver
     transplant.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**] [**Name (STitle) 128**] and 
     Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 318**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.  
     
     CONSENT:  After receiving explanation of the benefits and risks of the
     procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient. 
     
     TECHNIQUE:  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.  MAC
     anesthesia was provided by the anesthesiology team.  The patient's abdominal
     wall and two biliary drains were prepared in a sterile fashion.  0.035 Amplatz
     guidewires were advanced through the biliary tubes into the jejunum.  Tubes
     were removed over the wire and 7-French bright-tip sheaths were advanced into
     the biliary tree.  Pull-out cholangiograms from the right and left sides were
     obtained through the sheaths.  The right-sided cholangiogram showed free
     progression of contrast into the small bowel; however, the right hepatic duct
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     proximal to joining the left hepatic duct was noted to be stenotic and
     presumably did not respond to previous dilation. The left-sided cholangiogram
     showed some areas of strictured left bile duct. Decision was then made to
     dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was performed
     with 6 and 8 mm balloons.  The stenosed area in the right common bile duct as
     well as on the left and at the biliary-enteric anastomosis were dilated with 6
     and 8 mm cutting balloons.  Post-dilation cholangiograms showed opening of the
     stenosed areas with easier progression of contrast medium into the small
     bowel.  A new 10-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced over the wire
     on the right side and an 8-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced on
     the left side under fluoroscopic guidance.  Pigtails were formed in the
     jejunum and catheters were secured to the skin with an 0 silk stitch.  Right
     tube was connected to a drainage bag and the left tube was capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Pull-out cholangiograms showing stenosed areas in the right and left bile
     ducts, main bile ducts and biliary-enteric anastomosis.
     2)  Successful dilation with an 8-mm cutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3)  Placement of a 10-French biliary drainage catheter on the right and 8-
     French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,
5882,,,,3226-06-12 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"

     INDICATION:  Requirement for ongoing enteric feeding.
     
     TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS:  Procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], with
     Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**] supervising. Preprocedure timeout was performed to confirm patient
     identity and procedure.
     
     Under continuous fluoroscopic guidance, a 160 cm [**Location (un) 1426**]-[**Doctor First Name 1427**] 8-Fr feeding
     tube was advanced through the right nare into the stomach, and then advanced
     through the pylorus into the duodenum.  The tube was advanced into the third
     portion of the duodenum.  At this time, approximately 20 cc of Optiray
     nonionic contrast was injected, demonstrating appropriate location within the
     duodenum.  The tube was then affixed to the nose, and pinned to the patient's
     gown.
     
     No complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of postpyloric feeding tube, tip in the
     third portion of the duodenum.  Catheter is ready for use.
     
     
     

",,

5882,,,,3226-06-12 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"


     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                                                       *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic caths in place. Last
      study done on [**5-21**] which revealed 3 stenosis that were ballooned and caths were
      replaed with same size (10F on right and 8Fr on left). Pt has continued copius
      amts of leakage around right catheter. please do cholangio and pull back
      cholangiogram and balloon dilatation if needed. 
      Will upsizing of right catheter help stop leakage around exit site?
      Pt will need IV levo pre procedure. Please call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 342**] with results of
      study. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     HISTORY:  This is a 59-year-old man with biliary stenosis status post liver
     transplant.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**] [**Name (STitle) 128**] and 
     Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 318**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.  
     
     CONSENT:  After receiving explanation of the benefits and risks of the
     procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient. 
     
     TECHNIQUE:  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.  MAC
     anesthesia was provided by the anesthesiology team.  The patient's abdominal
     wall and two biliary drains were prepared in a sterile fashion.  0.035 Amplatz
     guidewires were advanced through the biliary tubes into the jejunum.  Tubes
     were removed over the wire and 7-French bright-tip sheaths were advanced into
     the biliary tree.  Pull-out cholangiograms from the right and left sides were
     obtained through the sheaths.  The right-sided cholangiogram showed free
     progression of contrast into the small bowel; however, the right hepatic duct
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     proximal to joining the left hepatic duct was noted to be stenotic and
     presumably did not respond to previous dilation. The left-sided cholangiogram
     showed some areas of strictured left bile duct. Decision was then made to
     dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was performed
     with 6 and 8 mm balloons.  The stenosed area in the right common bile duct as
     well as on the left and at the biliary-enteric anastomosis were dilated with 6
     and 8 mm cutting balloons.  Post-dilation cholangiograms showed opening of the
     stenosed areas with easier progression of contrast medium into the small
     bowel.  A new 10-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced over the wire
     on the right side and an 8-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced on
     the left side under fluoroscopic guidance.  Pigtails were formed in the
     jejunum and catheters were secured to the skin with an 0 silk stitch.  Right
     tube was connected to a drainage bag and the left tube was capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Pull-out cholangiograms showing stenosed areas in the right and left bile
     ducts, main bile ducts and biliary-enteric anastomosis.
     2)  Successful dilation with an 8-mm cutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3)  Placement of a 10-French biliary drainage catheter on the right and 8-
     French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,

     jejunum and catheters were secured to the skin with an 0 silk stitch.  Right
     tube was connected to a drainage bag and the left tube was capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Pull-out cholangiograms showing stenosed areas in the right and left bile
     ducts, main bile ducts and biliary-enteric anastomosis.
     2)  Successful dilation with an 8-mm cutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3)  Placement of a 10-French biliary drainage catheter on the right and 8-
     French catheter on the left.
     
     
     

",,
5882,,,,3226-06-12 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"


     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY        *
     * 47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * 74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                                                       *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      L 59 year old man with biliary stenosis s/p liver transplant with [**Hospital Unit Name 664**]/lat ptc
      Lat PTC is draining copiuos amts of bile around exit site.  
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic caths in place. Last
      study done on [**5-21**] which revealed 3 stenosis that were ballooned and caths were
      replaed with same size (10F on right and 8Fr on left). Pt has continued copius
      amts of leakage around right catheter. please do cholangio and pull back
      cholangiogram and balloon dilatation if needed. 
      Will upsizing of right catheter help stop leakage around exit site?
      Pt will need IV levo pre procedure. Please call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 342**] with results of
      study. 
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     HISTORY:  This is a 59-year-old man with biliary stenosis status post liver
     transplant.
     
     RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1350**] [**Name (STitle) 128**] and 
     Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 318**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.  
     
     CONSENT:  After receiving explanation of the benefits and risks of the
     procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient. 
     
     TECHNIQUE:  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table.  MAC
     anesthesia was provided by the anesthesiology team.  The patient's abdominal
     wall and two biliary drains were prepared in a sterile fashion.  0.035 Amplatz
     guidewires were advanced through the biliary tubes into the jejunum.  Tubes
     were removed over the wire and 7-French bright-tip sheaths were advanced into
     the biliary tree.  Pull-out cholangiograms from the right and left sides were
     obtained through the sheaths.  The right-sided cholangiogram showed free
     progression of contrast into the small bowel; however, the right hepatic duct
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-6-12**] 6:56 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     proximal to joining the left hepatic duct was noted to be stenotic and
     presumably did not respond to previous dilation. The left-sided cholangiogram
     showed some areas of strictured left bile duct. Decision was then made to
     dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was performed
     with 6 and 8 mm balloons.  The stenosed area in the right common bile duct as
     well as on the left and at the biliary-enteric anastomosis were dilated with 6
     and 8 mm cutting balloons.  Post-dilation cholangiograms showed opening of the
     stenosed areas with easier progression of contrast medium into the small
     bowel.  A new 10-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced over the wire
     on the right side and an 8-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced on
     the left side under fluoroscopic guidance.  Pigtails were formed in the
     jejunum and catheters were secured to the skin with an 0 silk stitch.  Right
     tube was connected to a drainage bag and the left tube was capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Pull-out cholangiograms showing stenosed areas in the right and left bile
     ducts, main bile ducts and biliary-enteric anastomosis.
     2)  Successful dilation with an 8-mm cutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3)  Placement of a 10-French biliary drainage catheter on the right and 8-
     French catheter on the left.

     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15031**]
     Reason: Pt s/p liver transplant with right and left transhepatic cat
      Contrast: OMNIPAQUE Amt: 40
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT
     (Cont)
     proximal to joining the left hepatic duct was noted to be stenotic and
     presumably did not respond to previous dilation. The left-sided cholangiogram
     showed some areas of strictured left bile duct. Decision was then made to
     dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was performed
     with 6 and 8 mm balloons.  The stenosed area in the right common bile duct as
     well as on the left and at the biliary-enteric anastomosis were dilated with 6
     and 8 mm cutting balloons.  Post-dilation cholangiograms showed opening of the
     stenosed areas with easier progression of contrast medium into the small
     bowel.  A new 10-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced over the wire
     on the right side and an 8-French biliary drainage catheter was advanced on
     the left side under fluoroscopic guidance.  Pigtails were formed in the
     jejunum and catheters were secured to the skin with an 0 silk stitch.  Right
     tube was connected to a drainage bag and the left tube was capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1)  Pull-out cholangiograms showing stenosed areas in the right and left bile
     ducts, main bile ducts and biliary-enteric anastomosis.
     2)  Successful dilation with an 8-mm cutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3)  Placement of a 10-French biliary drainage catheter on the right and 8-
     French catheter on the left.

     obtained through the sheaths.  The right-sided cholangiogram showed free
     progression of contrast into the small bowel; however, the right hepatic duct

     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:

      tubes
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through both catheters to
      assess leak, biliary dilation, strictures per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     MEDICAL HISTORY:  59-year-old man status post liver transplant, status post
     bilateral biliary drainage catheter placement, now present leakage around the
     catheter.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 317**] [**Name (STitle) **], Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1278**],
     Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.
     
     After the benefits and the risks were explained to the patient, a written
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the
     angiographic table.  Preprocedure timeout was obtained.  The patient's
     abdominal wall and preextsting catheters were prepped and wrapped in the
     standard sterile fashion.  15 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local
     anesthesia. 0.035 Amplatz guidewires were advanced through bilateral  biliary
     tubes into the jejunum. Tubes were removed over the wire and 7-French sheaths
     were advanced into the biliary tree.  Cholangiogram was performed from the
     right and left side through the sheath, which demonstrates stenosis of the
     right hepatic duct peripherally and left hepatic duct centrally.  Decision was
     made to dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was
     performed with 8-mm cutting balloon on the right hepatic duct and 8-mm
     noncutting balloon on left and right hepatic biliary duct.  Post dilation
     cholangiograms demonstrates both ducts appear patent.  New 8-French biliary
     drainage catheters were advanced over the wire on both sides under
     fluoroscopic guidance. Pigtails were performed in the jejunum and the catheter
     was secured to the skin.  Both catheters were capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-9-1**] 7:10 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15036**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 75
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     (Cont)

     1.  Cholangiogram demonstrates  stenosed areas in the right hepatic duct
     peripherally and stenosed area in the left hepatic duct centrally.
     2.  Successful dilatation with an 8-mm cutting balloon followed by an 8-mm
     noncutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3.  Successful placement of 8-French bilateral biliary drainage catheters.

     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 317**] [**Name (STitle) **], Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1278**],
     Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.
     
     After the benefits and the risks were explained to the patient, a written
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the
     angiographic table.  Preprocedure timeout was obtained.  The patient's
     abdominal wall and preextsting catheters were prepped and wrapped in the
     standard sterile fashion.  15 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local
     anesthesia. 0.035 Amplatz guidewires were advanced through bilateral  biliary
     tubes into the jejunum. Tubes were removed over the wire and 7-French sheaths
     were advanced into the biliary tree.  Cholangiogram was performed from the
     right and left side through the sheath, which demonstrates stenosis of the
     right hepatic duct peripherally and left hepatic duct centrally.  Decision was
     made to dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was
     performed with 8-mm cutting balloon on the right hepatic duct and 8-mm
     noncutting balloon on left and right hepatic biliary duct.  Post dilation
     cholangiograms demonstrates both ducts appear patent.  New 8-French biliary
     drainage catheters were advanced over the wire on both sides under
     fluoroscopic guidance. Pigtails were performed in the jejunum and the catheter
     was secured to the skin.  Both catheters were capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-9-1**] 7:10 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15036**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 75
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     (Cont)
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1.  Cholangiogram demonstrates  stenosed areas in the right hepatic duct
     peripherally and stenosed area in the left hepatic duct centrally.
     2.  Successful dilatation with an 8-mm cutting balloon followed by an 8-mm
     noncutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3.  Successful placement of 8-French bilateral biliary drainage catheters.

5882,,,,3226-09-01 00:00:00 EST,,,,,"RADIOLOGY_REPORT",,"


     DATE: [**3226-9-1**] 7:10 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15036**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 75
     ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
     * 47555 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO  47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         47525 CHANGE PERC BILIARY DRAINAGE C*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      47505 CHALNAGIOGRAPHY VIA EXISTING C*
     * -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         74363 BILIARY STRICTURE DILATION NO *
     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF            C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *
     * C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER  C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID,EP,NONLASER *
     ****************************************************************************
     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver transplant needs tube cholangiogram to check both
      tubes
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through both catheters to
      assess leak, biliary dilation, strictures per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     MEDICAL HISTORY:  59-year-old man status post liver transplant, status post
     bilateral biliary drainage catheter placement, now present leakage around the
     catheter.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 317**] [**Name (STitle) **], Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1278**],
     Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.
     
     After the benefits and the risks were explained to the patient, a written
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the
     angiographic table.  Preprocedure timeout was obtained.  The patient's
     abdominal wall and preextsting catheters were prepped and wrapped in the
     standard sterile fashion.  15 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local
     anesthesia. 0.035 Amplatz guidewires were advanced through bilateral  biliary
     tubes into the jejunum. Tubes were removed over the wire and 7-French sheaths
     were advanced into the biliary tree.  Cholangiogram was performed from the
     right and left side through the sheath, which demonstrates stenosis of the
     right hepatic duct peripherally and left hepatic duct centrally.  Decision was
     made to dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was
     performed with 8-mm cutting balloon on the right hepatic duct and 8-mm
     noncutting balloon on left and right hepatic biliary duct.  Post dilation
     cholangiograms demonstrates both ducts appear patent.  New 8-French biliary
     drainage catheters were advanced over the wire on both sides under
     fluoroscopic guidance. Pigtails were performed in the jejunum and the catheter
     was secured to the skin.  Both catheters were capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-9-1**] 7:10 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15036**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 75
     ______________________________________________________________________________

     (Cont)

     peripherally and stenosed area in the left hepatic duct centrally.
     2.  Successful dilatation with an 8-mm cutting balloon followed by an 8-mm
     noncutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3.  Successful placement of 8-French bilateral biliary drainage catheters.

     * 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON 75984 CHANGE PERC TUBE OR CATH W/CON*
     * -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      74305 TUBE CHOLANGIOGRAM            *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER       *
     * CATH, TRANSLUM ANGIO NONLASER        CATHETER, DRAINAGE                  *
     * CATHETER, DRAINAGE                   C1769 GUID WIRES INCL INF           *

     ______________________________________________________________________________
     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
      59 year old man s/p liver transplant needs tube cholangiogram to check both
      tubes
     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
      pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through both catheters to
      assess leak, biliary dilation, strictures per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     MEDICAL HISTORY:  59-year-old man status post liver transplant, status post
     bilateral biliary drainage catheter placement, now present leakage around the
     catheter.
     
     PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 317**] [**Name (STitle) **], Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1278**],
     Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 319**], the attending radiologist, was present and
     supervising throughout the procedure.
     
     After the benefits and the risks were explained to the patient, a written
     informed consent was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the
     angiographic table.  Preprocedure timeout was obtained.  The patient's
     abdominal wall and preextsting catheters were prepped and wrapped in the
     standard sterile fashion.  15 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied for local
     anesthesia. 0.035 Amplatz guidewires were advanced through bilateral  biliary
     tubes into the jejunum. Tubes were removed over the wire and 7-French sheaths
     were advanced into the biliary tree.  Cholangiogram was performed from the
     right and left side through the sheath, which demonstrates stenosis of the
     right hepatic duct peripherally and left hepatic duct centrally.  Decision was
     made to dilate the stenosed areas with cutting balloon plasty.  This was
     performed with 8-mm cutting balloon on the right hepatic duct and 8-mm
     noncutting balloon on left and right hepatic biliary duct.  Post dilation
     cholangiograms demonstrates both ducts appear patent.  New 8-French biliary
     drainage catheters were advanced over the wire on both sides under
     fluoroscopic guidance. Pigtails were performed in the jejunum and the catheter
     was secured to the skin.  Both catheters were capped.
     
     COMPLICATIONS:  There were no immediate complications.
                                                                 (Over)

     DATE: [**3226-9-1**] 7:10 AM
     BILIARY DILATATION                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 15036**]
     Reason: pt s/p liver transplant please do tube cholangiogram through
      Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 75
     ______________________________________________________________________________
                                     FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
     (Cont)
     
     IMPRESSION:
     1.  Cholangiogram demonstrates  stenosed areas in the right hepatic duct
     peripherally and stenosed area in the left hepatic duct centrally.
     2.  Successful dilatation with an 8-mm cutting balloon followed by an 8-mm
     noncutting balloon of the stenosed areas.
     3.  Successful placement of 8-French bilateral biliary drainage catheters.
